block.p: Thank you for your touching and important story about Arnold Blume (''Why Listen to the Substitute? At 81, He Tells History Firsthand,'' front page, April 4).

With grandchildren today often not living near their grandparents, an important influence on youth is being lost. Older teachers help fill that gap.

My mother taught elementary school for 30 years and retired at 65 to care for her mother, who had a stroke. After her mother died, she went back to school to volunteer two hours each morning and has continued to do so for the last 13 years.
She will turn 80 this summer. The children love her.

As a social work intern at a local senior center, I know many people in their 80s and 90s. I learn from their stories and from their way of being. Sure, they have their flaws like everyone, but I will miss the honesty, openness and goodness of this generation when they are no longer with us.
Mary Moore Delray Beach, Fla., April 4, 2007
